how_is_effectiveness_text_1.string: You’ve all shared a detailed report of the treatments you’ve tried in the past, those you found to be effective and the ones you’re currently taking. You’ve also reported the level of improvement in the overall severity of your condition and its specific clinical indicators (e.g frequency of outbursts).

how_is_effectiveness_text_2.string: All this data is normalized and optimized for analysis by machine learning models  developed specifically for treatment effectiveness ranking by the StuffThatWorks data scientists. (for those curious, it’s based on Bayesian Inference).

how_is_effectiveness_text_3.string: The model constantly looks at all this data and predicts the probability that a treatment will be effective and the impact it will have on the overall severity level and on the other clinical indicators.

how_is_effectiveness_text_4.string: These combine into an effectiveness score which allows ranking all treatments based on both the level of effectiveness and the certainty regarding that level, and keeps updating itself with every new report.

description.string:
Some of the world’s most complex problems can only be solved by crowdsourcing. Understanding treatment effectiveness is one of them.

Most of us dealing with a chronic condition spend hours online searching for better treatments because we feel no one has properly researched which treatments will work best for people like us.

description_additional_text.string: We’re right: nobody’s doing it, even for the most common or serious conditions, let alone more mundane or rare ones. It’s just too expensive to conduct large-scale patient interviews, and most medical research is done on very small groups of people. The result? The treatments we get are far from being optimized for us.

content.string: Just like Wikipedia, Waze or Kickstarter, when people come together for a common cause the result can be huge. We should be driving the research about our condition: we know how treatments affect us, and collectively we have more information than any organized research could ever gather. Together, we can build the world’s richest and most up-to-date database for treatment effectiveness, and use it to learn more about our condition— underlying causes, patterns in symptoms, comorbidities and which treatments work best for each of us.

People dealing with chronic conditions share their experience in an organized survey. This data is then normalized, anonymized and analyzed using advanced machine learning algorithms that are programmed to look for valuable insights—for the entire condition community, for subgroups and for individuals. The insights are shared with the community, where members can comment, discuss and pose new research questions.

Community members take an active role in determining the research direction. It only takes a few dozen people completing the survey to start generating useful insights. The more people join and contribute their information, the smarter and more personalized the insights become.

StuffThatWorks was created by Yael Elish, a core member of the Waze founding team. The idea was born after Yael spent a decade helping family members cope with medical conditions. She searched online endlessly and found that, time and again, other people were the key to discovering the most effective treatments.

Out of this experience, a small team of highly motivated people came together to create StuffThatWorks. Experts in crowdsourcing, machine learning, and medical research, StuffThatWorks is backed by three reputable VC firms, Bessemer Venture Partners, 83 North and 10D.

This is a journey that can only succeed with people’s participation. We see proactive individuals, patient advocacy groups and researchers as an extension of our team, and we invite you to join us on the road ahead.
If you share our vision and enjoy early stage building, be among the first people to start a community. Contact us

description.string: StuffThatWorks is led by a world-class team with expertise in crowdsourcing, data science and machine learning.

A passionate entrepreneur with expertise in crowdsourcing and consumer-facing products, Yael was on the Waze founding team, where she drove the overall product strategy that led the company from User One to one of the world’s most notable crowdsourcing endeavours. She also co-founded eSnips and NetSnippet, and was part of the senior management team that took Commtouch to its successful NASDAQ IPO in 2000.

With a background in physics, Yossi has spent over 10 years working in the field of data science. He has extensive experience in hands-on analysis, machine learning, AI and managing global data teams. Prior to StuffThatWorks, Yossi was VP Research at Kenshoo (Digital Marketing) where he led a global team of data scientists in building optimization and measurement solutions for their customers.

description.string: This policy explains how Stuff That Works LTD. ("STW" or "we"), uses cookies, similar tracking technology and your related choices. For more information on other ways we collect and use information from you and your use of our website, at https://www.stuffthatworks.health ("Website"), and our mobile Application ("App") please see our Privacy Policy at: https://www.stuffthatworks.health/legal/privacy-policy ("Privacy Policy"). In this Cookie Policy we use the term "cookies" to refer to any applicable tracking technologies described herein. Any capitalized terms not otherwise defined in this Cookie Policy shall have the meaning ascribed to them in the Privacy Policy.

content.string:
• Cookies are small text files that are stored on your device to help websites and mobile apps remember things about you. Session-based cookies last only while your browser is open and are automatically deleted when you close your browser. Persistent cookies last until you or your browser delete them or until they expire. To learn more about cookies, visit http://www.allaboutcookies.org/.
  • Pixel Tags (also known as web beacons or clear GIFs) are transparent images, iFrames, or JavaScript placed on a website or in marketing emails that are used in order to understand how you interact with such websites or emails.
  • Social Media Features, such as the Facebook “like” button, may collect your IP address and which page you are visiting on a website, and may set a cookie to enable the feature to function properly. Your interactions with these features are governed by the privacy policy of the company providing the relevant Social Media Features.
  • Single Sign-on allows you to log in to certain websites or mobile applications using sign-in services provided by third parties, such as Facebook or Google. These services will authenticate your identity and provide you the option to share certain personal information with us such as your name and email address to pre-populate our sign-up form.
  • Ad ID is a unique number issued to you by an entity which received your permission to serve you with advertisements. The Ad ID allows persons or entities with whom you interact to gather and store information they learn about you in connection with your Ad ID. Most entities that have assigned you with an Ad ID allow you to delete or change such Ad ID and thereby prevent third parties from collecting information concerning your behavior across multiple sessions. To learn more about Ad ID and how change or delete it on Android and Apple, please refer to https://www.androidguys.com/tips-tools/how-to-disable-personalized-ads-on-android/ and https://support.apple.com/en-il/HT205223.

title.string: WHAT ARE COOKIES AND SIMILAR TECHNOLOGIES?

content.string:
The cookies we use can be classified in one of the following categories:
Strictly necessary cookiesWe use these cookies in order to enable you to use our Website's features, such as enabling movement between pages and remembering information you enter on forms. Without these necessary cookies, certain services on our Website will not be possible and our Website will not perform as smoothly as it should.
Security cookiesWe use these cookies to help identify and prevent security risks.
Performance and analytics cookiesWe use these cookies to collect information about the use of our Website in order to help improve the way it works.

We use the following First and Third-Party Cookies:
Cookie NameTypePurpose / Functionality / Policies & LinksExpiry
stw-session1st party Performance and Analytics cookiesHolds information about the current session on the website0.5 hours
STWUTM1st party Performance and Analytics cookiesHolds information about the UTM Campaigns the user arrived with30 days
stw-session-link1st party Performance and Analytics cookiesHolds information about the link the user landed with in the first arrival (changes every time the user lands in a new page)7 days
stw1st party Strictly Necessary cookiesHolds the login information (user-id)13 months
stw-anonymous1st party Performance and Analytics cookiesHelps us to recognize the user between multiple login attempts (browser/device identifier)13 months
stw-temp1st party Performance and Analytics cookiesHolds information about a new user before they sign up3 hours

description.string: Dr. Eyal Leshem, expert in epidemiology and infectious diseases, is a guest researcher at the CDC in Atlanta and a consultant to the World Health Organization (WHO). He received his MD from the Technion and completed a residency in internal medicine and a fellowship in infectious diseases at the Sheba Medical Center. In 2014, he completed his training as an epidemic intelligence service (EIS) officer at the CDC. He is director of the Center for Travel Medicine and a clinical associate professor in Tel Aviv University School of Medicine.

Professor Amir Tirosh is a leading endocrinologist, specializing in endocrinology and diabetes. He received his MD and Ph.D. from Ben Gurion University Medical School and completed a residency in internal medicine at Sheba Medical Center, and a fellowship in endocrinology and diabetes at the Brigham and Women’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School in Boston, MA. He also holds a joint faculty appointment at Harvard Medical School, Sheba Medical Center, and Tel-Aviv University.

Dr. Lavie is an expert in pediatrics and pediatric pulmonology. She is the director of the Pediatric Pulmonology Ward at Tel Aviv Medical Center and a faculty member at the Tel Aviv University School of Medicine. She directs clinics and oversees research in respiratory related areas including asthma, congenital and genetic lung diseases, infectious diseases of the lungs and more. Dr. Lavie is also involved in medical innovation and MedTech, a center working to promote early stage medical technologies.
By sharing information about the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on your daily life, you can play a major role in helping advance research.

title.string: WHAT CAN THE SHARED INFORMATION REVEAL?
COVID-19 and the Impact on People with Pre-Existing Conditions

answer.string: Anyone dealing with an ongoing medical condition, mundane or severe, is eager to find the most effective treatment for themselves or a family member. Many of us dedicate endless hours researching, speaking with others and scanning groups. We want to know if there are treatments that will work better, if our side effects are unusual, or if changes in diet, lifestyle or vitamins could make a difference. We look for people similar to ourselves and seek to learn what works (and doesn’t) for them. What if there was one place that gathered data and experiences from thousands of patients and organized it in a way that made it easy to figure out which treatment will work best for someone like you? That’s what StuffThatWorks was created to do. We are using crowdsourcing to build the world’s largest, most comprehensive database of Patient Reported Outcomes (PROs) focusing on treatment effectiveness for every medical condition.

question.string: Why was StuffThatWorks created?

answer.string: StuffThatWorks was created by a core member of the Waze founding team who spent years helping her daughter struggle with a condition that, while considered “mundane,” was taking a heavy toll on her and the family’s day to day life. Months of online research driven by the belief that others, somewhere, must have experienced something similar, led to the discovery of a medical treatment that was more effective than what was prescribed. In fact, the condition improved dramatically and years of suffering came to an end. It turned out this experience was not unusual. The answers are out there. The individuals who have tried various treatments know best what has worked. All that’s missing is a way to empower them to share this data in an organized fashion that’s optimized for analysis. Similar to how Waze sought to empower people to build maps and share data to help each other bypass traffic, here, too, crowdsourcing presents the optimal solution to a large scale problem.

question.string: Where did the idea come from?

answer.string:
Every condition has hundreds of possible unique treatments including medications, surgeries, supplements, special diets, lifestyle changes and more. The effectiveness of these treatments is impacted by countless factors ranging from age, gender, comorbidities and even climate, lifestyle and more. Because of this, producing statistically viable information about which treatments will work best for subgroups of people and even individuals requires collecting data from millions of individuals worldwide and on an ongoing basis.

This kind of project is too costly for any one organization or institution to take on. Crowdsourcing presents an ideal solution. Just like Wikipedia, Waze or Kickstarter, when people come together for a common cause the result can be huge.

question.string: Why crowdsourcing?

answer.string:
It’s simple:
  • It starts with everyone sharing their treatment experiences by answering a series of questions about their condition in an organized way.
  • This data is then anonymized and analyzed by smart machine learning algorithms programmed to identify which treatments work best.
  • The collective knowledge and discoveries are shared with members in the community page.
  • As the community grows, insights are discovered about treatment effectiveness. As more people contribute, the insights become more personalized.
  • This can only happen with your help. Everyone can pitch in by inviting others to become contributors, adding research questions and steering the research direction.

question.string: How does StuffThatWorks work?

answer.string: When you collect information from millions of people on a daily basis across hundreds of conditions, big data is formed. When a team of smart researchers, engineers and data scientists apply cutting edge natural language processing and machine learning AI to this data, the potential is enormous. That is the core of StuffThatWorks, a large multidisciplinary team focused on harnessing this data to create valuable insights, uncover underlying patterns and reveal effective treatments.

question.string: Where does Artificial Intelligence (AI) come in?

answer.string: The information you share becomes part of the database and helps everyone learn more about the condition and treatment effectiveness. It is also used to provide you with personalized information about which treatments can work for people like you. While general insights are available quickly, personalized insights rely on a large number of people joining the database.

question.string: What’s in it for me?

answer.string: Generating statistically viable insights about what’s effective for small subsets of the population and/or individuals takes time and requires a large number of responses. We are just getting started, and it will take time to learn which treatments will work for you. But even when a community is small, you can already discover valuable information about symptoms, aggravating factors, comorbidities and more. As more people contribute, the data improves and the insights become more interesting and more accurate. That’s where you can help! Invite others to join, post on social and media, and help millions of people find the best treatment for their condition.

question.string: How long will it take to get personalized treatment effectiveness insights?

answer.string: Crowdsourcing works when everyone pitches in! In order to generate personalized insights about what treatments work best for your condition, thousands of people need to participate. You can help make this happen by inviting others to your community in Facebook groups, on Twitter, in Reddit, Instagram and more. If you’re part of an advocacy organization for your condition, you can ask them to help spread the word as well.

question.string: What’s the best way to get others to contribute to the research?

answer.string: Absolutely! Like everything at StuffThatWorks, communities are started and driven by you. Search for your condition on our homepage. If it’s not yet open, we encourage you to start it! All it takes is a dash of proactivity and a shared vision. Start by taking the survey and then invite others to do the same. The community will open once a few dozen people have contributed.

question.string: Can I open a research community for my condition?

answer.string:
Patients themselves are the key to understanding chronic conditions, and we believe that they should have the power to help drive the research being done on their condition. As a StuffThatWorks community member, you earn points for your contributions. You receive points each time you post or respond to a question, join a discussion, rate an insight, or contribute new data.
In the future, you will be able to use these points to help make decisions about what research will be done within your community. Think of them as a type of currency that can be invested in supporting the research that matters most to you.

question.string: How can community members be involved in the research?

answer.string:
Patient Reported Outcomes (PROs) or Patient Reported Outcome Measures (PROMs) is the official medical term that describes data gathered from the real world and from patients themselves about their general health, or a specific medical condition.

Information based on PROs is enormously beneficial to the medical world, but can be hard to gather, particularly on a large scale. Researchers use PROs to study conditions in depth, and they can offer doctors a more holistic view of their patients’ health status. PROs can also be used to triage patients, identify comorbidities and help reduce side effects.

Traditionally, PROs are gathered within the context of a study or by a doctor. There has never been a way to gather PROs on a large scale or on an on-going basis, from the vast majority of patients who are not actively taking part in a study or reporting on their experiences.

With the StuffThatWorks platform, vast numbers of community members contribute PROs on an ongoing basis, adding new data to the knowledge base in real time, and sharing their experiences with different treatments. Because the data on StuffThatWorks is dynamic and updated regularly, it is particularly valuable for advancing research and medical discoveries.

question.string: What are Patient Reported Outcomes and why are they so powerful?

answer.string:
To find valuable insights, large numbers of people need to participate. No single doctor, hospital, university or organization can do this alone. Using traditional methods, the task is too big and the cost is exorbitant. Collecting and analyzing information from millions of people can only happen when individuals come together, en masse, to share their experiences.

Crowdsourcing has other advantages as well. It offers a real-time picture of disease by harnessing information as individuals are diagnosed or even before, and thus it is uniquely positioned to improve diagnostics and surveillance of illness. By gathering large numbers of PROs, we are also able to learn about aspects of disease dynamics that are not accessible through traditional data, such as contact patterns and aspects of the social environment.

question.string: Why is crowdsourcing an ideal way to gather Patient Reported Outcomes (PROs)?

answer.string:
The treatment effectiveness surveys collect personal health information and general demographic details. The surveys also ask about the treatments tried, their effectiveness, side effects and more. The responses are anonymized to protect privacy and then added to the database where machine learning algorithms analyze the data for important insights.

In the future, we plan to enrich the database by gathering data from additional surveys, and through integrations with other healthcare apps, wearable devices, medical records, genetic testing and more.

question.string: What kind of data do you collect at StuffThatWorks?

answer.string:
We have a professional team of data scientists dedicated to ensuring the validity and accuracy of our Patient Reported Outcome (PRO) surveys and the data they collect. The database was designed and built from scratch, with an enormous amount of time and thought put into the phrasing and taxonomy. The information is collected in a structured way, making it easy to analyze using our algorithms.

The database is regularly monitored and updated to ensure that our data is scientifically rigorous and can be confidently applied both to generate meaningful insights, and for research purposes within the medical community.

question.string: How do you ensure the quality of your data?

answer.string:
Before being entered into our database, all of the patient reported data is anonymized and normalized. This is done to protect user privacy, to reduce redundancies and to ensure the overall quality of our data.

 Once the data is organized in the database, we use state-of-the art machine learning models to compare and rank the real-world effectiveness of different treatments for various conditions, based on large numbers of patient-reported outcomes. Many of our survey questions are open ended. Because of this, we use Natural-Language Processing (NLP) to analyze participants’ responses and generate insights about symptoms, comorbidities, treatments and more. 

When analyzing treatment effectiveness reports, our models look at the attributes of the treatment in question (type of treatment, chemical compound, pharmaceutical classes etc.) as well as the attributes of the member who reported that treatment. The models account for member biases towards certain types of treatments as well as biases that arise from the specific demographic distribution of our members. As more data is collected, the models become more personalized and are able to better account for these biases. In other words, as each community grows, the insights become more accurate for specific subsets of people. Whenever new insights are discovered, they are shared with all community members who have that condition.

question.string: How does your analysis work?

answer.string:
Our goal is to advance research about medical conditions, with a focus on learning which treatments work best, and for whom. 

To date, medical research has been limited by prohibitive costs and the challenges of performing research on large sample sizes. StuffThatWorks represents a revolutionary solution to this problem. Our advanced algorithms are able to identify important information based on large groups of patients about the effectiveness of treatments, correlations between conditions, side effects and more.

question.string: How will the data be used?

answer.string: Transparency and giving users control over the data they share are at the core of what we do. We apply the highest level of security standards to all of our data, and are of course compliant with all applicable privacy laws. We encourage you to read our Privacy page and Terms of Use to learn more about the steps we take to protect our users and their data. We conduct regular tests and reviews of our privacy and security measures, both internally and with a trusted third party. We also have an in-house Data Protection Officer (DPO) who is responsible for ensuring that we are completely compliant with the most up-to-date privacy standards and practices. He can be reached at dpo@stuffthatworks.health. Please note, however, that while privacy is a main priority at StuffThatWorks, no security procedure can provide absolute information security. We do not and can not guarantee that unauthorized access will never occur.

question.string: What about privacy?

answer.string: We employ industry best practices to keep your information secure and private including the separation, encryption, de-identification and anonymization of your personal information. All processing and analysis is performed on a separate database made up of anonymized, normalized and aggregated data that does not include any personally identifying information.

question.string: What measures are taken to keep personal information secure?

answer.string: We regularly test and review our privacy and security measures, both internally and with a trusted third party. Our development process includes built in mechanisms to ensure that new products and features pass a legal review and comply with privacy standards. We also have an in-house Data Protection Officer (DPO) who is responsible for ensuring that we are completely compliant with the most up-to-date privacy standards and practices. He can be reached at dpo@stuffthatworks.health. Access to any personally identifiable information is restricted to key personnel at StuffThatWorks for the purpose of maintaining the integrity of the database. All access is logged to prevent abuse.

question.string: Are there internal processes within the company to ensure privacy protection?

answer.string: Absolutely not. We will never sell your personal information to any third parties.

question.string: Will you sell my personal information?

answer.string:
When you contribute to a StuffThatWorks community, you share details about your experiences with a medical condition. In doing so, you are helping advance research and discover which treatments work best, and for whom. Some of what you share is used to generate a report that can help others with your condition learn more.

Reports contain details about your condition, symptoms and treatments you’ve tried, but no personally identifying information. The report is matched to your nickname and avatar, and you can choose whether or not to share it with the community. Please note sharing is mutual—reports are only visible to fellow community members who also share theirs.

question.string: What is my report and who can see it?

answer.string: Within your condition community, you always appear as the nickname and avatar that you choose. We recommend selecting a nickname that is anonymous and non-identifying. Your comments, discussions and questions in the community are only visible to members of that community. To protect your own privacy, we recommend carefully considering what you post in the community. Keep in mind that specific information you share may make it possible for others to guess your identity.

question.string: Can I contribute anonymously within my community?

answer.string: Yes, you can delete your account at any time by sending in a request to support@stuffthatworks.health. If you delete your account, all of your information will be permanently removed from our system within 30 days.

question.string: Can I delete my personal health information?

answer.string: We’re here to help. To contact us please send an email to support@stuffthatworks.health

question.string: I still have more questions. Can I speak with someone from StuffThatWorks?

answer.string: The member similarity map is a visual representation of all the contributors on StuffThatWorks (it is not sorted by geographic proximity). The contributors are placed according to their similarity to one another based on a long list of information pieces - ranging from age and quality of life to symptoms and aggravating factors. Based on this data, they are placed on the map - the more similar their health profile is, the closer they will be. Currently, there are more than 1 million contributors represented on the map, with more being added every day, so the map is constantly updating.

question.string: What is this map?

answer.string:
Since every contributor, across more than 580 conditions (with more added constantly) currently available on StuffThatWorks, is represented, what we end up getting is a map of chronic conditions and how they relate to one another. The research potential that such information entails is staggering.
First, the map is diagnostic in nature: it places users on the map without accounting for their formal diagnosis, and only later we color the dots according to said diagnosis. That means that potentially, the map can identify misdiagnosis - when a yellow dot appears in a sea of red, for example, or when someone is placed in the very periphery of his conditions’ “neighborhood”. It can also tell how “typical” someone’s condition is - possibly informing the patient and their doctors of alternative approaches for treatment beyond the baseline protocol.
Since it is based on individual similarities, it also allows each user to locate and even contact those who resemble them - not just members of the condition at large, but those who most likely experience the condition in the most similar way. The advice and inputs that such connections might entail can prove crucial.
The map also offers an exploration of the connection and similarities between the different conditions as a whole. The data collection process is consistent, organized and unified across all conditions, and therefore allows a comparative view of them side-by-side. Overlaps and proximity, for example, might suggest a more meaningful, perhaps even clinical, connection which can then be further explored by medical researchers. 
Furthermore, since the map is constantly and automatically updating, new information - and new conditions, as well - are easily and quickly incorporated into the map, allowing new insights about lesser-known conditions to emerge - such as the Long-COVID and Fibromyalgia finding.

question.string: Why is it meaningful/important? What can we learn from it?

answer.string: This type of cross-condition analysis, especially in this magnitude, is possible only on a platform such as StuffThatWorks. One reason is the crowdsourced model allows for extremely large numbers and data points that are hardly tenable in other forms of research; but mostly because of our emphasis on consistent survey questions across conditions. The carefully-crafted survey enables us to employ comparative analysis, in a methodical and quantifiable way, which is rarely possible when researching conditions separately.

question.string: What makes it innovative?

answer.string: Each dot represents a single contributor on StuffThatWorks. The dot and its location are essentially a reduction of various information pieces about the user such as age, sex, quality of life, symptoms, etc. Each contributor can see their own dot on the map.

question.string: What do the dots mean?

answer.string:
The colors represent the different condition categories according to the official diagnosis reported by the contributor. The colors are added retroactively, the formal diagnosis of each member is not part of the input to the model which determines the location of the dots. More often than not, people diagnosed with the same condition do end up clustered together, which end up creating those patches of color, or condition territories. Less often, one can find a dot of one color within a territory controlled predominantly by another - which potentially might indicate a misdiagnosis.
Either way, similar colors do not necessarily insinuate similarity in conditions - it is a visual tool to allow a better reading and understanding of the map.

question.string: What do the different colors mean?

answer.string: Since the dots represent the members of StuffThatWorks, the size of a condition “patch” is determined solely by the number of members on that community. While we believe there are good reasons why some communities are larger than others, on the map the patch size has no clinical significance.

question.string: Why are some conditions so much larger than others?

answer.string:
The distance (or overlap) between conditions is an extension of the distance between dots. As we’ve learned, each dot represents a single user, whose location was determined by an array of data points derived from the information they provided (age, sex, symptoms, etc.).
The location of this dot is decided by the similarity of each piece of data to the same piece of data of other users. Therefore, the distance between dots - and ultimately between conditions - is a representation of the overall similarity between them, once the different pieces which compose a user’s dot were reduced to two-dimensions.
Overlaps of condition categories tend to indicate conditions with similar characteristics among its members.

question.string: What do the distances or overlaps between conditions mean?

answer.string: The x and y axes in and of themselves have no real meaning except in that conditions that are close to one another in the graph are likely to be described by our users in a similar way. The two dimensions are a visualization of a process called embedding, which is a way of giving a numerical representation to non-numerical data.

question.string: What are the X and Y axes?

answer.string:
The calculation process we use is called “embedding.” Each user is represented by multiple pieces of information, and each one is represented by a number. Therefore, theoretically, the map showing these dots by their distance from one another should have been multidimensional. In fact, our condition fit model creates a user embedding of 512 dimensions, which means that each user is represented by 512 different numbers.
This representation is then squeezed down to two dimensions - X and Y - through a process called dimensionality reduction. There are different approaches to dimensionality reduction, but we use an approach called t-SNE (t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding). The way it works is as follows: first, it calculates the distances between each point and its nearest neighbors in the full embedding space, then it creates a new embedding with the chosen number of dimensions (in our instance, two). It then optimizes this new embedding space to try and preserve as much as possible the same distances proportionally between nearest neighbors as in the original space.

question.string: How is this distance calculated?

answer.string: If a member belongs to multiple different communities on StuffThatWorks, and has filled the survey for each of those conditions, this member will be represented by one dot per survey - meaning they will be displayed multiple times, once per condition.

description.string: StuffThatWorks is led by a world-class team with expertise in crowdsourcing, data science and machine learning.

A passionate entrepreneur with expertise in crowdsourcing and consumer-facing products, Yael was on the Waze founding team, where she drove the overall product strategy that led the company from User One to one of the world’s most notable crowdsourcing endeavours. She also co-founded eSnips and NetSnippet, and was part of the senior management team that took Commtouch to its successful NASDAQ IPO in 2000.

A mathematician specializing in algebraic geometry and sheaf theory, Ron is passionate about using computational and scientific machineries for the common good. For 10+ years, he led one of the top technological units in the Israeli Intelligence Corps, and also has extensive hands-on experience in research and analysis. Ron was the 2015 recipient of the prestigious Israel Defense Prize.

With a background in physics, Yossi has spent over 10 years working in the field of data science. He has extensive experience in hands-on analysis, machine learning, AI and managing global data teams. Prior to StuffThatWorks, Yossi was VP Research at Kenshoo (Digital Marketing) where he led a global team of data scientists in building optimization and measurement solutions for their customers.

content.string:
Our core belief at StuffThatWorks is that people can and should take a more active role in their contribution to researching and treating the chronic conditions they live with. Influencing and impacting the research and study into chronic conditions is only the first step. The trove of anonymized and verified data we make freely open to patients and patient advocacy groups can empower people to explore invaluable insights previously unavailable anywhere.

With 430,000 contributors across 270+ chronic medical conditions, StuffThatWorks is already  the largest and most sophisticated RWE knowledge base optimized for research and offering invaluable insights to patients, caregivers, and researchers. In addition, StuffThatWorks is a lively community where the sharing of knowledge and experience provides much more than just mutual moral support to its members.

title.string: Where sharing experience makes a difference

description.string: People living with chronic conditions come together on StuffThatWorks to improve their own wellbeing and help others through crowdsourcing of personal experiences.

title.string: Crowdsourcing personal experience for chronic condition relief

title_2.string: Crowdsourcing the biggest and most sophisticated RWE knowledge base

title_3.string: Finding what works for chronic conditions through crowdsourcing and data

title_4.string: Discovering stuff that works for chronic conditions

title_5.string: Leveraging big data to find relief for chronic conditions

content.string:
It’s hard to come to terms with the fact that most (if not all) people living with chronic conditions are diagnosed and treated on a trial and error basis. It’s also quite infuriating, especially if you consider just how much time and resources most chronically ill people invest in the search for a miracle remedy or even moderate relief.

Finding what works for people living with chronic conditions is an ongoing challenge for both patients and the medical community. Academic studies conducted on small samples of population in laboratory conditions often lack mass applicability. The reason for that is obvious; large-scale studies over lengthy periods of time are costly. Moreover, no matter how extensive and expensive a study is, the results can never truly reflect real world experiences (RWE) for a large enough sample of the observed population.

Integrating RWE data into medical research has long been the golden grail of researchers looking to gain educated insights of the efficacy of treatments for chronic conditions. Up until recently this gap was technically impossible to bridge.

title.string: Help discover what works for your condition

content.string:
Today, the majority of RWE data is scattered across apps, databases, social network posts and condition-specific communities on and off-line. The data is unstructured, disorganized and unreliable. That, of course, if the personal experiences are even shared with anyone aside from the individual’s primary caregivers. What the medical community and patients need is the opposite: statistically viable information about what has worked best and for whom.

This urgent and critical need, combined with the technologies available for machine learning and big data, led us to create StuffThatWorks.health - a one-of-a-kind database of real world experience data collected from people living with various chronic conditions and trying different solutions and treatments.

StuffThatWorks empowers people with chronic conditions to transform their experience into an organized knowledge database. The information shared about ourselves, and how we experience the condition and the treatments, is then analysed by StuffThatWork’s machine learning algorithms. This lets us unfold valuable information about the condition, the treatments and which treatments work best and for whom. Clearly, the more contributors join the platform, the more personalized and accurate the insights get. This is why StuffThatWorks allows anyone to start a community for their specific condition and invite others to share their experience and knowledge. At StuffThatWorks you will find people just like you sharing their experience and discovering together what works over time. You can ask questions in a structured, research-like format to get crowdsourced answers with both quantitative and qualitative result data.

long_bio.string: An orthopedic surgeon and professor, Dr. Alexander Blankstein is considered a world-class specialist in using ultrasound for diagnostic orthopedics, and has published over 85 articles in medical journals. He is a professor at the Sackler School of Medicine at Tel Aviv University, and a practicing senior orthopedic surgeon. After graduating from the Sackler School of Medicine, Dr. Blankstein honed his surgical skills at top hospitals worldwide. He completed his orthopedic residency at Israel’s Sheba Medical Center and continued his training at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, MN, the Henry Ford Medical Center in Detroit, MI, and the Cantonal Hospital Basel-Land (KSBL) in Basel, Switzerland. Dr. Blankstein serves as a professional consultant for several of Israel’s HMOs and is on the editorial board of the World Journal of Orthopedics, a leading publication in the field.

love_stw.string: By empowering the millions of people suffering from chronic illness to share their treatment experiences, a treasure chest of information becomes available to others battling the same conditions, and to the medical community treating these patients. Nothing compares to first-hand experience—and by sharing these experiences we all become wiser. I am a firm believer in anything that can truly help sick people across the world without causing any harm—that’s my mantra...

other_activities.string: I stay active and love sports, although nothing too extreme. I enjoy traveling in Israel and around the world, especially in Switzerland. I worked there many years ago, and my daughters were born there so I feel a special connection to the country. I spend a lot of time with my large family and am blessed to have 11 grandchildren. I also play the piano and enjoy researching musculoskeletal ultrasound imaging.

long_bio.string: Dr. Ramani Durvasula is an expert on narcissism and narcissistic abuse, a licensed clinical psychologist, a professor of psychology at California State University, Los Angeles, and CEO and Founder of LUNA Education, Training & Consulting. She was also the national recipient of the American Association of University Women Recognition Award for Emerging Scholars in 2002. The focus of Dr. Durvasula’s clinical, academic and consultative work is the etiology and impact of narcissism and high-conflict, entitled, antagonistic personality styles on human relationships, mental health, and societal expectations. Dr. Durvasula’s research on personality disorders has been funded by the National Institutes of Health and she is a consulting editor of the scientific journal Behavioral Medicine. Dr. Durvasula has also been a participant in the governance of the American Psychological Association, most recently as the chair of the STAY-MHSAS Training Advisory Committee of the Minority Fellowship Program. Dr. Durvasula has appeared at SxSW, TEDx, and many other television and media platforms including Red Table Talk, the Today Show, Oxygen, Investigation Discovery, and Bravo. She is also a featured expert on the digital media mental health platform MedCircle.

love_stw.string: The opportunity for people to share their stories about their health and contribute to what we know helps create community and a sense of “I’m not alone” for people experiencing a range of health issues. I have really enjoyed witnessing the evolution of data and seeing what works, what doesn’t, and what people need more information about. Traditional methods of data collection and presentation often result in long lags in reporting, and the real time results of the data gathered via StuffThatWorks is important for informing ongoing research, clinical interventions, and hypothesis formation.

other_activities.string: I work too much; it’s my greatest problem, and work-life balance is non-existent for me. I am always writing, outlining videos, or writing patient charts, and while it’s not healthy, it’s what I do.  In a more balanced world and life, I would be binge-watching documentaries and the next best series on my streaming services, or reading a new book with my lovely cat at my side. I would be sitting with friends, children or partner, and starting to re-enter the world, or watching absurd reality TV with my sister. Los Angeles is a beautiful place, so maybe I would take a long meandering drive to the mountains, desert, or ocean. I would play board games or bake desserts with my daughter. I love to travel, and perhaps someday will find myself doing that again. When I am really on it, I do get myself hoisted on the treadmill and give it a whirl....

love_stw.string: In addition to their typically small sample size and lengthy timelines, far too many clinical studies are run by pharmaceutical companies, where there is a significant risk of bias. StuffThatWorks not only delivers unbiased information about the effectiveness of different treatments, but also empowers its community members to lead the direction of the research, creating relevant data points from their first-hand experiences, which otherwise may have remained unknown or unexplored. I believe in StuffThatWorks because it captures and organizes the “Wisdom of Crowd,” which is not only unbiased but can also reveal significant information that can solve important clinical problems.

other_activities.string: I mentor medical students in humanism and professionalism as well as in oncological research. In my private life, I am the mother of four children whom I love to spend time with. In particular, we love hiking together.

Dr. Rothschild received her medical degree at the Paris XII Kremlin-Bicetre Medical School before moving to Israel where she completed her pediatric residency at the Meir Medical Center. During her time at Meir, she created the pediatric day care unit. She went on to sub-specialize in medical genetics at the Sheba Medical Center, and then returned to France to pursue a one-year research fellowship at Necker Enfants-Malades Hospital in the Genetic Department, where her studies focused on uncovering the genetic cause of a rare lysosomal disease. Following her fellowship, Dr. Rothschild joined the team at Hadassah Medical Center as a senior pediatric medical geneticist. In this role, she treated patients with rare lysosomal storage diseases, while also teaching genetics at the Hebrew University Medical School where she was an assistant professor. From 2012 to 2014, Dr. Rothschild headed the Genetics Department at Meir Medical Center. In 2014, she moved to her current position at the Sheba Medical Center as the Director of the Institute for Rare Diseases. From 2013-2014, Dr. Rothschild served on the Commission for Rare Diseases in the Israeli Ministry of Health, and she is the current Israeli Coordinator for the Orphanet Rare Disease European consortium.

love_stw.string: StuffThatWorks can connect parents to other parents and caregivers, and promote research worldwide. Indeed, dealing with rare diseases means, by definition, that the information is sparse. Knowing the natural history of a rare disease is needed not only to care for the affected child but also to evaluate the impact of therapies. Crowdsourced data is crucial to offering better care for patients. In my vision, the value of crowdsourcing is that it offers a much needed addition of information directly from the people affected by illness, and it allows for cooperation among parents, medical teams, pharmaceutical companies, decision makers and more. StuffThatWorks is needed in order to provide better care for the community of patients with rare diseases.

other_activities.string: I love spending quality time with my children and grandchildren, and I love being at the beach, hiking, and riding horses.

short_bio.string: A senior pediatrician and medical geneticist, Dr. Rothschild is the Director of the Institute for Rare Diseases at the Edmond and Lily Safra Children Hospital at the Sheba Medical Center. She graduated from the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Paris XII (Kremlin Bicetre) and is an associate professor in pediatrics at the Sackler School of Medicine at Tel Aviv University.

description.string: StuffThatWorks is supported by a talented team of medical professionals and research advisors who provide insight and guidance on our product and research.

  2. The second type of information is individually identifiable information ("Personal Information"). This information may identify an individual or may be of a private and/or sensitive nature.   3. In addition, we may collect Special Categories of Personal Data when you choose to add this information to your account. This includes information you provide about your ethnicity, health or medical conditions or treatments. We use the information to recommend relevant posts or communities to you which match the conditions, health topics or ethnicity. For avoidance of doubt, any Non-Personal Information connected or linked to any Personal Information shall be deemed as Personal Information as long as such connection or linkage exists. Personal and Non-personal Information which is being gathered in connection with your use of the Service may consist of the following:

The User may automatically provide us with certain technical Non-personal Information and aggregated usage information, such as the User's mobile device brand and model, operating system type and version, browser information, language, screen resolution, geolocation, altitude, which Third Party Services’ applications are installed on the User’s device and User’s uses thereof through the Service, the User's manual configurations, 'click-stream', session recordings, interactions and activities on the Service, the period of time the User used the Service and related timestamps, crash and error logs, etc.

You may choose to share with us more information from your social network account (such as Facebook) or other service providers. When you connect to the social network account through the Service for the first time or otherwise make the Service interact with your social network account, you will be asked to permit the social network to share your personal information stored on such social network with the Service. title.string: WHAT IS THE LEGAL BASIS FOR USE?

content.string:
We may use information that we collect about you for the following purposes:
  • To provide, operate and improve our Service through features such as data analytics and manage our business;
  • To find and analyze the correlations between different groups of patients and treatments;
  • To personalize our service to you by generating insights for our Users and connecting patients with similar conditions so that they may share their treatment histories and experiences, ensuring a better User experience;
  • To provide the medical world with a research platform where only de-identified and aggregated data is accessible.
  • To send you updates, notices, notifications, announcements, and additional information related to the Service;
  • To be able to manage your account and provide you with customer support;
  • To display or send to you marketing and advertising material and general and personalized content and advertisements via the Service, email, postal mail, telephone and/or mobile devices;
  • To develop, display, and track content and advertising tailored to your interests on our Service and other sites, including providing our advertisements to you when you visit other sites;
  • To create cumulative statistical data and other cumulative information and/or other conclusive information that is non-personal, in which we and/or our business partners might make use of in order to operate and improve our Website and provide related services;
  • To perform scientific and market research and improve treatment options for patients. With your consent, we may share your information with our Partners in industry, government and/or academia for research purposes, as more fully described below. We may share de-identified or aggregated data for research purposes only;
  • To perform functions or services as otherwise described to you at the time of collection;
  • To prevent, detect, mitigate, and investigate fraud, security breaches or other potentially prohibited or illegal activities;
  • To comply with any applicable rule or regulation and/or respond to or defend against legal proceedings brought against us or our affiliates.

description.string: Stories showcasing what’s possible when people are empowered to advocate for their own health, or the health of their loved ones.

formatted_summary.string: Bethan Youd has Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome, or PCOS. It’s a hormonal condition so common that one in ten women of reproductive age have it. Many of them, like Bethan, will be told upon diagnosis that it’s primarily a reproductive issue that can cause fertility problems. But Bethan’s message is that although it can mean difficulties getting pregnant, it should also be seen and treated as an overall medical condition – one that can cause significant weight gain that is not easily remedied by intensive exercise and diet, as well as blood sugar spikes, irregular periods, inflammation and hair loss. In this episode Bethan explains what major holistic based changes in lifestyle and how she eats has helped her overcome her symptoms.

title.string: PCOS: One woman’s holistic path to weight loss and healing

formatted_summary.string: When Heather Foisy was diagnosed with an autoimmune illness called Sjogrens as a young woman she felt her world was falling apart. The disease had already been making her nauseous at every meal, and had caused such bad abdominal pain that even walking down the hallway could bring her to tears. But now, with the diagnosis, depression and loneliness set in. At the same time, however, so did a measure of denial. Heather, intent on distracting herself, continued to go out frequently with her hard-partying friends. That is, of course, until her body crashed and she realized she had to retool her life, all the way down to the way she socialized and made friends.  In this episode Heather describes what she learned in forging a supportive network of friends and family in the wake of chronic illness.

title.string: Chronic Illness: How to build a supportive network

formatted_summary.string: Laura Nichols is a 23-year-old British software developer, gamer and musician. As a child, Laura struggled to make friends, was teased and bullied, but was baffled as to why. She thought she was broken and needed fixing. As a teen, her mental health spiraled downwards. At 17, she had begun to self-harm and a perceptive school mental health nurse suggested for the first time that she might be autistic. The diagnosis that followed proved to be a revelation. She found support and began to thrive.

title.string: Female and Autistic: The Power of a Diagnosis

formatted_summary.string: Sara Gorman was diagnosed with Lupus at 26, just six weeks after her wedding. She and her new husband's plans to have a family were put on hold as she worked to stabilize her condition. In this episode, Sara speaks candidly about how getting healthy helped her reach her goal of embarking on a high risk pregnancy. She offers tips for others on how to best prepare for and navigate pregnancy with a chronic condition.

title.string: Navigating Pregnancy When You Have a Chronic Illness

formatted_summary.string:
Our pandemic times have upended healthcare and given telemedicine a rocket boost, but what does that mean for your health or your loved ones with chronic illness? What can and can't be done via telemedicine? What at-home physical devices are helpful to have?
In this episode, Dr. Chavi Karkowsky, a high-risk pregnancy doctor in a leading New York City hospital, breaks it down for all of us.

title.string: How Telehealth Can Empower Patients & Improve Access

formatted_summary.string: Amelia Mardon’s experience with pelvic pain began at age 12, amid heavy periods, intense period pain, and fatigue so bad it sometimes kept her out of school for half the month. Eventually, she was diagnosed with endometriosis. Her long journey with endometriosis is now fueling her life’s work as a researcher trying to apply what we know about pain science to women with persistent pelvic pain.

title.string: Endometriosis and the Science of Pelvic Pain

formatted_summary.string: Paula Dumas has suffered from migraine most of her life, at times enduring migraine attacks 25 days a month. The creator of MigraineAgain, she now applies her decades of experience in business and marketing to help people cope with migraine. In this episode, Paula shares how migraine treatment is experiencing a “breakthrough moment,” with new medicines and therapies changing people’s lives.

In her 40+ years battling Hidradenitis Suppurativa, a debilitating, inflammatory illness, Denise Fixen has learned a lot about how to speak to doctors and advocate for her own health and the health of others. The wisdom she’s collected over the years can benefit anyone navigating chronic illness. Here she shares her story and her tips.

title.string: How to Be a Patient Advocate: Advice from an HS Patient

formatted_summary.string: Mascha has two chronic illnesses: ulcerative colitis, and a rare condition called primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). Mascha hit a low point three years ago and decided to take her psychological and physical health into her own hands. She embarked on what she now calls her "year of healing," focusing on the interconnected nature of mind and body.

Heather-Elizabeth Brown was a healthy 35-year-old from Detroit, Michigan, who, shortly after contracting COVID-19, found herself hospitalized, as her lungs began to fail. She spent 31 days on the ventilator and six months later she has yet to fully recover from her symptoms.

title.string: My Month on a Ventilator with COVID

formatted_summary.string: Maya Wolff, a singer-songwriter and former professional dancer, was in the best shape of her life when she got COVID-19. Seven months later, her life remains upended by shortness of breath and debilitating exhaustion. She is one of tens of thousands of COVID “long-haulers,” struggling through the aftermath of an unpredictable illness whose symptoms won’t go away.

title.string: Long-Haul Covid-19: When the Symptoms Won’t Go Away

formatted_summary.string: For two decades, Sabrina Rubin Erderly tried to power through the excruciating pain of migraine attacks, and hide the toll the disease was taking on her. She thought that to acknowledge the disease's impact on her life was to admit defeat, even though some days it felt like an ice-pick was hacking at her brain. Today, she is finally speaking out about migraine's impact on her life.

title.string: Coming Out of the Migraine Closet

formatted_summary.string: Phantom limb pain is the very real, sometimes excruciating pain and discomfort that occurs even when that limb  no longer exists because it’s been amputated. As many as 80 percent of amputees experience it. Listen in to this conversation between two experts: Kiera Roche, a life-long athlete whose right leg was amputated below her knee after a car accident and Keren Fisher, a psychologist and researcher who helps people adjust to limb difference.

title.string: How to fight the pain of Phantom and Residual Limb Pain

formatted_summary.string: For 15 years Joe Landson lived with a mysterious illness, one that is little understood and lacking in effective treatment. He is one of an estimated 30 million people with chronic fatigue syndrome, or myalgic encephalomyelitis. Compounding the illness is the stigma around it. So often doctors and even loved ones doubt what Joe calls, "a disease no one can see."

In Jessica Apple’s home, diabetes lightning struck twice. First her husband was diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes, and then, a few years later, Jessica was diagnosed. At this point they were parents to three young boys and desperate to take some control back of their health. For them, a low-carb, high-protein diet has been key to controlling their blood sugar.

At 21, Natalie Hayden was embarking on a career in television journalism when she was struck by fatigue, fevers and debilitating pain. She was soon diagnosed with Crohn’s Disease, and eventually left her career in journalism to become a full time health advocate. She went from investigating the news to investigating how the body responds to Crohn's.

title.string: From TV Journalist to Crohn's Health Advocate

formatted_summary.string: Annette Leonard went from being an able-bodied advocate for disability rights to a woman struggling to make it through the day after being diagnosed with several chronic illnesses.She describes her journey to accept her new life and as she puts it, finding “wellness in the midst of illness.”

Laura and Lynda live on opposite ends of the world, but have become a lifeline of information and support for one another as they both cope with Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder, PMDD, a severe form of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) that can upend daily life and relationships.

When Oded Grinstein found out his baby daughter had a rare and deadly cancer, he searched around the world for a doctor and treatment plan that might save her. He describes his personal quest to help his daughter and the organization he created, My Child’s Cancer, to help other parents of children with cancer do the same.

title.string: Saving Shani: A Father’s Battle to Save His Daughter from Cancer

formatted_summary.string: Dr. Jo Shapiro is a surgeon and a professor at Harvard Medical School. When she became sick with COVID-19, she found herself fascinated by, and even studying, how her body was experiencing the disease. She shares what she learned about COVID-19 from the point of view of both doctor and patient.

Majorie Ingall is a writer and editor in New York City. She was sick with the COVID-19 alongside her husband and two children, and describes what it was like to be fighting the virus together as a family under the same roof, each experiencing the same virus in entirely different ways.

Skyler is a millennial managing a chronic illness. It took Skyler years to get a diagnosis for Lupus and she describes what it's like to be a young person who had to connect the dots between mystifying symptoms in order to be taken seriously by doctors.

title.string: Lupus: A Millennial Connects the Dots

formatted_summary.string: Shlomo, founder of a hi-tech startup in San Francisco, describes what it felt like to have COVID-19. Although he has asthma, Shlomo experienced what would be called a “mild case” but, like so many others in that category, he still found himself battling extreme tightness in his chest, and, at moments, even struggling to breathe.

Ellie Angold, a college student in California, has Celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder of the gut triggered by gluten proteins in wheat and other grains. Her case is so severe that even trace amounts of gluten can leave her violently ill. When she found out there was such a thing as a gluten detection dog she decided to train a dog herself.  So she bought an Australian Shepherd puppy and got to work. This is their story.
Tanya shares the long, hard road of learning coping strategies and skills for herself so she could best care for her non-verbal autistic daughter who requires 24/7 support.

title.string: The Caretaker: A mother’s journey caring for her daughter with severe autism

formatted_summary.string: Monique Cohen was determined to take on her Parkinson’s Disease diagnosis with the same rigor and pro-active approach that made her as a leading expert in international microfinance. When researching Parkinson’s – a neurodegenerative brain disorder that can cause tremors, stiffness, and slowness of the body, as well as muffled speech and balance problems, she found out that exercise could help slow its progression. In this episode she describes how physical exercise from training in therapeutic boxing to strength training as well as starting speech therapy has helped her reduce and manage the impact of Parkinson’s, a disease which effects some 10 million people around the world.

title.string: The Power of Exercise to Slow Parkinson's Disease

formatted_summary.string: Nathan Edwards was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease, a lifelong chronic autoimmune disease that inflames the intestines. Nathan spent the first decade after his diagnosis searching for a treatment that would help ease his symptoms, but became frustrated that most medications made little impact. At age 28, Nathan decided to do something about it, and embarked on a quest to implement a strict elimination diet and meticulously journal its impact on his health. It has not been a perfect journey, but Nathan has been able to control his symptoms for the most part, through diet.

title.string: The Holy Grail: Finding Relief from Crohn’s Disease through Diet

formatted_summary.string: Kaitlyn Cervi, a 33-year-old medical student, recently found out she has Multiple Sclerosis, an incurable disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, gradually causing serious disability. While medication helps manage her MS, Kaitlyn sees her daily exercise routine as essential to staying ahead of the disease.

Yvonne Barber, 43, has struggled with PCOS since she was a teenager. Symptoms like weight gain, acne and excess facial hair took a daily toll. Excess facial hair meant years of waxing, shaving and hair removal creams, sometimes resulting in rashes and infections. But then Yvonne decided to end the "torture" and grow in what she calls her "lady beard."  She now works to normalize her new look for others with PCOS to help them learn how to "own it" and not be ashamed.

Some call it "sleeping beauty syndrome." Its actual name is Kleine-Levin Syndrome. It’s a rare and complex neurological disorder that causes excessive sleepiness. Between episodes, those with KLS appear totally healthy, but when the disorder strikes, a person with KLS can sleep up to 23 hours a day, getting up only to eat and use the bathroom. In this episode, we hear from siblings Dani Farber and Arielle Poleg; they were the first sibling pair ever known to both have KLS.

Nutrition and health coach Clare McAfee was diagnosed with Interstitial Cystitis in 2016. IC is a chronic condition causing bladder and pelvic pain—so terrible that Clare compares it to living with shards of glass in her bladder all the time. She eventually discovered that a hormone imbalance was at the root of her condition. Though doctors told her she'd never be cured, she set out to find effective treatment on her own. Today, thanks to a combination of treatments, Clare's IC is in remission.

title.string: A research community as seen by a contributing member
Starting a research community takes minutes

description.string:
The data you share can help millions and revolutionize medicine.
But it’s extremely important that you have a full understanding of how your privacy is protected and how your data is used.

content.string: View our FAQs about Privacy read our legal Privacy Policy and Terms of Use or contact our DPO at dpo@stuffthatworks.health.

title.string: Have more questions about privacy and security?
What happens to the data you share

content.string: You share details about your experiences with a medical condition. In doing so, you are helping advance research and discover which treatments work best, and for whom. As more people share, the data quality and research potential grow exponentially.

Your information is normalized, anonymized and entered into a secure, AI-powered database dedicated to storing and analysing PROs. The database is the first of its kind, created entirely by crowdsourcing real patient experiences for hundreds of conditions.

title.string: The data becomes part of the knowledge base.

content.string: Smart AI algorithms generate insights from the aggregated, anonymized data, which are then shared with community members, researchers and medical experts. Your personal information is NEVER revealed, shared or sold.

title.string: The data is analyzed and insights are shared.

content.string: The report contains details about your condition, symptoms and treatments you’ve tried, but no personally identifying information. The report is matched to your nickname and avatar, and you can choose whether or not to share it with the community. Shared reports are only visible to fellow community members who also share theirs.

title.string: Some of your info is used to generate a report that can help others.

content.string: Transparency and giving you control over the data you share are at the core of what we do. We are, of course, fully compliant with all relevant digital privacy standards, including all applicable digital privacy laws.

We employ industry best practices to keep your information secure and private. This includes the separation, encryption, pseudonymization and anonymization of your personal information. All processing and analysis is performed on a separate database made up of anonymized, normalized and aggregated data that does not include any personally identifying information.
Access to personally identifiable information is restricted to key personnel at StuffThatWorks for the purpose of maintaining the integrity of the database. All access is logged to prevent abuse.
We never sell, trade or transfer any personally identifying information to third parties.

We employ an in-house Data Protection Officer (DPO) responsible for ensuring that we're always on par with the latest privacy and security standards. Feel free to contact him at dpo@stuffthatworks.health.

title.string: How We Protect Your Privacy and Security

content.string: Within your condition community, you always appear as the nickname and avatar that you choose. We recommend selecting a nickname that is anonymous and non-identifying.
Consider exactly what you post in the community, and remember that specific information you share may make it possible for others to guess your identity.
Your comments and discussions in the community are only visible to members of that community.
You decide whether or not your report is shared with the community. Sharing is mutual—when you share your report, it’s only available to other members who also shared theirs.
You can choose to edit or hide certain details of your report at any time.
You can request to leave the community and delete your account and data at any time by contacting us. If requested, your data will be permanently erased from the database within 30 days.
We will never sell, trade or transfer any personal information to any third parties.

title.string: Your Privacy Options - You control the information you share
What happens to the data you share
How we protect your privacy and security

description.string: Stuff That Works Ltd. (“STW”) and its affiliates (collectively “STW”, “Company” “we” or “us”) respect the privacy of its users, including its registered members, (“User(s)” or “you”), and are committed to protect the personal information that you share with us in connection with the use of www.stuffthatworks.health (The “Website” or “Site”), the App, and/or the Service (as defined in the TOU). This Privacy Policy (the “Privacy Policy”) is intended to describe our practices regarding the information we may collect from you when you use the Service, the manners in which we may use such information, and the options and rights available to you. We believe that sharing experiences with one another may improve understanding in health and treatments and helps to form a better support network for Users. Since this may include you sharing sensitive information about your health, we also believe it is important to be transparent about our privacy policies. Capitalized terms which are not defined herein, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in our Terms of Use available at https://www.stuffthatworks.health/legal/terms-of-use (the “TOU”), which this Privacy Policy is incorporated thereto by reference. YOUR CONSENT – PLEASE READ CAREFULLY. By entering, connecting to, accessing and/or using the STW services, you agree to be bound by the terms and conditions set forth in this privacy policy, including to the collection and processing of your personal information (as defined below). Please note: you are not obligated by law to provide us with any personal information. You hereby acknowledge and agree that you are providing us with personal information at your own free will, for the purposes described in Section 4 below, and that we may retain such personal information in accordance with this privacy policy and any applicable laws and regulations.

content.string:
STW’s Service is based on the information our Users provide us and share with other users, as such the benefit from the use of our platform for our Users is based on the crowdsourcing of information provided by such Users. We may collect different types of data and information from our Users:
  1. The first type of information is non-identifiable and anonymous information (“Non-personal Information”). We are not aware of the identity of the User from which we have collected the Non-Personal Information. Non-Personal Information is any unconcealed information which is available to us while Users are using the Service. Non-personal Information which is being gathered consists of technical information and behavioral information (e.g the browser type and version, device type).
  2. The second type of information is individually identifiable information (“Personal Information”). This information may identify an individual or may be of a private and/or sensitive nature. Personal Information which is being gathered consists of any personal details provided consciously and voluntarily by the User. The Personal Information is collected from the details the Users provide when Users wish to contact us or register as a member to the Service, which requires Users to complete a comprehensive registration survey containing the personal and medical details of the patient, as more fully described in our TOU. Types of Personal Information that Users may submit include, among others: name, avatar, email address, password, age, phone number, date of birth, gender, location, mailing address, IP address, profile picture, biographic, demographic and geographic information. (a) Please note that healthcare professionals who provide services to our registered members, and may be identified as such on our Site and App, may share with us certain additional Personal Information including, but not limited, to the such User’s credentials to practice medicine, medical license identification numbers, and CVs.
  3. In addition, we may collect Special Categories of Personal Data when you choose to add this information to your member account. We rely on your explicit consent to process this type of data for these purposes. This includes information you as a registered member, provide about your ethnicity, health or medical conditions or treatments.  We use the information to create for you an individualized report, accessible only to you and to recommend relevant posts or communities to you which match your demographics, medical conditions and health topics. We also allow you to share this information with other registered members in your member community if you choose, under a registered member nickname and avatar, at your discretion. No one outside of your member community and without reciprocal share settings will have access to this personal information. You can also withdraw your consent at any time by removing this information from your account.
For avoidance of doubt, any Non-Personal Information connected or linked to any Personal Information shall be deemed as Personal Information as long as such connection or linkage exists. Personal and Non-personal Information which is being gathered in connection with your use of the Service may consist of the following:
  • Technical Information. The User may automatically provide us with certain technical Non-personal Information and aggregated usage information, such as the User's mobile device brand and model, operating system type and version, browser information, language, screen resolution, geolocation, altitude, which Third Party Services’ applications are installed on the User’s device and User’s uses thereof through the Service, the User's manual configurations, 'click-stream', session recordings, interactions and activities on the Service, the period of time the User used the Service and related timestamps, crash and error logs, etc.
  • Information from Social Networks and Other Service Providers. When contacting our Service via Facebook or other social networks or platforms (as applicable), we may have access to your public profile, which includes your name, profile picture, gender, age group and residency.
